unittitle.value: The Dolliver Romance. MS in Sophia Hawthorne's hand of the story, "Another Fragment of the Dolliver Romance."

unitid.value: Berg Coll MSS Hawthorne, N. m.b.

physdesc.value: [17 written sides, with one verso note].

note.value: "The first chapter [A Scene from the Dolliver Romance] was published in the “Atlantic” as an isolated portion, soon after his death; and subsequently the second chapter, which he had been unable to revise, appeared in the same periodical [Another Scene from the Dolliver Romance]. Between this and the third fragment there is a gap, for bridging which no material was found among his papers; but, after hesitating for several years, Mrs. Hawthorne copied and placed in the publishers’ hands that final portion, which, with the two parts previously printed, constitutes the whole of what Hawthorne had put into tangible form."

bibliography.value: First published in The Dolliver Romance and Other Pieces, Boston: James R. Osgood & co., 1876.

note.value:
"The spinster who has just been blest / Finds solemn thirty much improved / By proofs that such a crabbed soul / Is still remembered & beloved. / Kind wishes 'ancient Lu' has stored..."
Louisa May Alcott was born Nov. 29, 1832, so implies a date following November 29, 1862.
See Rita K. Gollin, "Louisa May Alcott's 'Hawthorne'", The Concord Saunterer, Fall 1980 (15:3), p. 16-19.

unittitle.value: Tappan, [Caroline], letter to. Sep. 5, [1851]. Copy in the hand of SAPH.

unitid.value: Berg Coll MSS Hawthorne, N. m.b.

physdesc.value:
[6 written pages] with envelope (George Parsons Lathrop) inscribed "Copy of Amusing letter from N. H. To Mrs Tappan, in Lenox, 1851 (Sept 5th)."
Typed note, 1 slip.

bibliography.value:
Centenary Edition, XVI, The Letters 1843-1853, p.481, #508.
The CE text is taken from version printed in magazine The Century XLVII (November, 1894), 93-94, and editors state that the source for this was "probably a transcript of [N.H.'s] draft by SH included in a letter to Elizabeth P. Peabody, now unknown". This is appears to be the conjectured transcript.
Another version of the letter was published in Rose Hawthorne Lathrop's Memories of Hawthorne (1897), 163-67. The CE rejects most variant readings from Memories, but all of these reflect the letter as copied in this transcript.

unittitle.value: Hathorne [Hawthorne], William, letter to the Right Honorable [William Morrice, Secretary of State]. Oct. 26, 1666. Copy in unknown hand, note in NH's hand.

unitid.value: Berg Coll MSS Hawthorne, N. m.b.

physdesc.value:
[10 written pages].
1 page addressed to "Nathaniel Hawthorne Esq. | Consul of the United States of America | Liverpool." with note by NH:
"Copy of a letter supposed to have been written by Major William Hawthorne, of Massachusetts, defending that Colony against the accusations of the Commissioners of Charles II, and excusing the General Court for declining to send over Governor Bellingham and himself, in compliance with the King's orders. (From the State Paper Office, London, Rec.d July 24th 1856.)

note.value: Nathaniel Hawthorne spells his ancestor's name anachronistically as "Hawthorne," the spelling NH himself had adopted, rather than "Hathorne," the original spelling.

physloc.value: m.b. (Hawthorne, Nathaniel)

unittitle.value: Wilcox, J. A. J., line engraving on steel, 1883.

physdesc.value:
Portrait used in volume V of the 1883 Standard Library edition of The Works of Nathaniel Hawthorne in fifteen volumes. According to Rita Gollin, in Portraits of Nathaniel Hawthorne, Wilcox, who worked as a photographer in Boston from 1860 on, "was particularly admired for his line engraved portraits" (84).
Enclosed with letter to President Buchanan.
